p: Three different studies on wild plants traditionally used for human consumption in Portugal and Spain quoted C. hypocistis as famine food; its nectar was sucked as sweets or spread on rye bread during the working day to avoid hunger pains [ 6, 7, 16]. From the nutritional point of view, flowers can be divided into three major components (pollen, nectar, and petals) and other parts, which can play a role in human nutrition [ 17]. Nectar is the second most important component; it is usually a sweetish liquid which contains a balanced mixture of sugars (fructose, glucose, and sucrose), amino acids, proteins, inorganic ions, lipids, organic acids, phenolic substances, alkaloids, and terpenoids, among others [ 18].
